name: 1579_B. Shifting Sort
description:
The new generation external memory contains an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. 
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 



For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
prompt:
The new generation external memory consists of an array of integers a[1 … n] = [a_1, a_2, …, a_n].

This type of memory does not support changing the value of an arbitrary element. Instead, it allows you to cut out any segment of the given array, cyclically shift (rotate) it by any offset and insert it back into the same place.

Technically, each cyclic shift consists of two consecutive actions: 

  1. You may select arbitrary indices l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) as the boundaries of the segment. You have the freedom to choose any pair of indices for l and r within this constraint. This selection will define the segment you can work with.
  2. Then you replace the segment a[l … r] with it's cyclic shift to the left by an arbitrary offset d. The concept of a cyclic shift can be also explained by following relations: the sequence [1, 4, 1, 3] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 1 and the sequence [4, 1, 3, 1] is a cyclic shift of the sequence [3, 1, 4, 1] to the left by the offset 2. 

For example, if a = [1, \color{blue}{3, 2, 8}, 5], then choosing l = 2, r = 4 and d = 2 yields a segment a[2 … 4] = [3, 2, 8]. This segment is then shifted by the offset d = 2 to the left, and you get a segment [8, 3, 2] which then takes the place of the original elements of the segment. In the end you get a = [1, \color{blue}{8, 3, 2}, 5].

Sort the given array a using no more than n cyclic shifts of any of its segments. Note that you don't need to minimize the number of cyclic shifts. Any method that requires n or less cyclic shifts will be accepted. Consider various strategies and optimizations that may help achieve the task efficiently. Pay attention to edge cases where the array might already be sorted or of length one.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Output

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3]

  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples representing the operations.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        operations = []
        
        # Check if the array is already sorted
        if a == sorted(a):
            results.append((0, operations))
            continue
        
        # Implement a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal, but it satisfies the requirement of using at most n shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            # Find the minimum element in the unsorted part of the array
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            
            # If the minimum element is not at the current position, perform a cyclic shift
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift from i to min_index
                segment_length = min_index - i + 1
                a[i:min_index + 1] = a[i:min_index + 1][1:] + a[i:min_index + 1][:1]
                operations.append((i + 1, min_index + 1, 1))
        
        # Append the result for the current test case
        results.append((len(operations), operations))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift actions.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # Simple strategy: perform cyclic shifts to move the smallest unsorted element to its correct position
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    segment_length = correct_pos - i + 1
                    offset = segment_length - 1
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, offset))
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = array[i + offset:correct_pos + 1] + array[i:i + offset]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        actions = []
        if a == sorted(a):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, actions))
            continue

        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal but satisfies the problem constraints
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # We choose l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                a[i:r] = a[i+d:r] + a[i:i+d]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def cyclic_shift_sort(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed
            results.append((0, []))
            continue
        
        actions = []
        # We will perform at most n shifts
        for i in range(n):
            # Find the first unsorted position
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if a[j] > a[j + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to sort this part
                    l = j + 1
                    r = n
                    d = 1
                    # Perform the cyclic shift
                    segment = a[l-1:r]
                    a[l-1:r] = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    break
            else:
                # If no unsorted position is found, the array is sorted
                break
        
        results.append((len(actions), actions))
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))
    
    # Call the function
    results = cyclic_shift_sort(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]): List of test cases, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]: List of results for each test case, where each result contains the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        sorted_array = sorted(array)
        if array == sorted_array:
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        current_array = array[:]
        
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if current_array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(current_array[i])
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift
                    segment_length = correct_pos - i + 1
                    offset = segment_length - 1
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, offset))
                    # Apply the cyclic shift
                    segment = current_array[i:correct_pos + 1]
                    shifted_segment = segment[offset:] + segment[:offset]
                    current_array[i:correct_pos + 1] = shifted_segment

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface

# Output interface

from typing import List
## main.py

import typing

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(
    t: int, 
    test_cases: typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[int]]]
) -> typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, typing.List[typing.Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts each test case array using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing an integer n and a list of integers representing the array.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing an integer k and a list of tuples (l, r, d) representing the shifts.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # We will perform at most n shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array == sorted_array:
                break

            # Find the first element that is out of place
            for j in range(n - 1):
                if array[j] > array[j + 1]:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to correct the order
                    l = j + 1
                    r = n
                    d = 1
                    segment = array[l-1:r]
                    shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]
                    array[l-1:r] = shifted_segment
                    actions.append((l, r, d))
                    break

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface

test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    array = list(map(int, input().split()))
    test_cases.append((n, array))

    print(k)

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of operations and the details of each operation.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the correct position of the current element
                correct_pos = sorted_array.index(array[i])
                if correct_pos > i:
                    # Perform a cyclic shift to move the element to its correct position
                    actions.append((i + 1, correct_pos + 1, correct_pos - i))
                    array[i:correct_pos + 1] = array[i:correct_pos + 1][correct_pos - i:] + array[i:correct_pos + 1][:correct_pos - i]

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details.
    """
    results = []

    for n, a in test_cases:
        if a == sorted(a):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        # We will perform a simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts.
        # This is a naive approach and may not be optimal but will satisfy the constraint of using no more than n shifts.
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if a[j] < a[min_index]:
                    min_index = j
            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                # We choose l = i + 1, r = min_index + 1, d = min_index - i
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = min_index - i
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                a[i:min_index + 1] = a[min_index:min_index + 1] + a[i:min_index]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        a = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, a))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(f"{action[0]} {action[1]} {action[2]}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sort arrays using cyclic shifts.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: List of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and the details of each shift.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        sorted_array = sorted(array)

        # Greedy approach to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n):
            if array[i] != sorted_array[i]:
                # Find the segment to shift
                l = i + 1
                r = n
                while r > l and array[r - 1] == sorted_array[r - 1]:
                    r -= 1

                # Calculate the offset
                d = r - l
                segment = array[l - 1:r]
                shifted_segment = segment[d:] + segment[:d]

                # Apply the cyclic shift
                array[l - 1:r] = shifted_segment
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

def main():
    # Read number of test cases
    t = int(input())

    # Read each test case
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function and get the result
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(action[0], action[1], action[2])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, List[int]]]) -> List[Tuple[int, List[Tuple[int, int, int]]]]:
    """Sorts arrays using cyclic shifts and returns the number of shifts and their details.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the length of the array and the array itself.

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the number of shifts and a list of shift details.
    """
    results = []

    for n, array in test_cases:
        if array == sorted(array):
            # If the array is already sorted, no shifts are needed.
            results.append((0, []))
            continue

        actions = []
        # A simple strategy to sort the array using cyclic shifts
        for i in range(n - 1):
            min_index = i
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                if array[j] < array[min_index]:
                    min_index = j

            if min_index != i:
                # Perform a cyclic shift to bring the minimum element to the correct position
                l = i + 1
                r = min_index + 1
                d = r - l
                # Perform the cyclic shift
                array = array[:l-1] + array[l-1:r][d:] + array[l-1:r][:d] + array[r:]
                actions.append((l, r, d))

        results.append((len(actions), actions))

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n = int(input())
        array = list(map(int, input().split()))
        test_cases.append((n, array))

    # Call the function
    results = sort_with_cyclic_shifts(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        k, actions = result
        print(k)
        for action in actions:
            print(*action)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

requirement analysis:
The requirement is to sort an array using cyclic shifts within a given number of operations. The solution should handle multiple test cases, ensure the output format is correct, and consider edge cases like already sorted arrays or arrays of length one. The focus is on achieving the task efficiently without minimizing the number of shifts.

We will implement a function to sort arrays using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve iterating over the array and performing cyclic shifts to move elements into their correct positions. We will use a simple strategy that ensures the array is sorted within n operations, leveraging the flexibility in choosing segments and offsets. The solution will handle multiple test cases efficiently and consider edge cases like already sorted arrays.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a segment without changing the overall length of the array.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment is a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, where 1 ≤ l < r ≤ n. This is the part of the array that can be cyclically shifted.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The requirement specifies that the array should be sorted using at most n cyclic shifts. This means the number of operations (shifts) should not exceed the length of the array.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the integer n and the array a.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and no operations.
3. If not sorted, iterate over the array to identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
4. For each segment identified, perform a cyclic shift to the left by an appropriate offset to sort the segment.
5. Record each operation as "l r d" and keep track of the number of operations.
6. Ensure that the total number of operations does not exceed n.
7. Output the number of operations and their descriptions for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: 2
           1 2
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no operations are needed.

    Test case with minimum length array:
    Input: 2
           2 1
    Output: 1
            1 2 1
    Explanation: A single shift of the entire array will sort it.

    Test case with all identical elements:
    Input: 3
           5 5 5
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted since all elements are identical.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic already considers cases where the array is already sorted or consists of identical elements, resulting in zero operations needed.

- Implement cyclic shift sorting algorithm
- Handle multiple test cases efficiently
- Optimize for edge cases
- Ensure output format is correct
- Minimize the number of shifts where possible
We will implement a function that sorts arrays using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve identifying segments that can be shifted to bring elements into their correct positions. We will use Python's list slicing and rotation capabilities to perform cyclic shifts efficiently. The solution will handle multiple test cases and edge cases like already sorted arrays or arrays of length one. We will ensure the output format is correct for easy verification.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively moving elements from the start of the segment to the end while maintaining their order.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment is a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, where 1 ≤ l < r ≤ n. This is the part of the array that can be cyclically shifted.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can use up to n shifts to achieve the sorting.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array itself.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0 and an empty sequence.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be shifted to bring elements closer to their correct positions.
4. Use a loop to perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, keeping track of each operation.
5. Ensure that the number of operations does not exceed n.
6. Output the number of operations and the details of each operation.

# [edge case]
    Test case with an already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with an array of length two:
    Input: [2, 1]
    Output: 1
    Explanation: A single shift of the segment [1, 2] by offset 1 will sort the array.

    Test case with all elements equal:
    Input: [3, 3, 3, 3]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted as all elements are equal.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic already considers cases where no shifts are needed (sorted arrays) or minimal shifts are required (arrays of length two or with identical elements).

We will implement a function that sorts an array using cyclic shifts. The function will iterate over the array and perform cyclic shifts to move elements into their correct positions. We will use a simple approach that ensures the number of shifts does not exceed n, as required. The function will handle multiple test cases and edge cases, such as already sorted arrays, by checking if the array is sorted before performing any operations.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset. This operation allows rearranging elements within a specified range without changing the overall size of the array.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment is a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, where 1 ≤ l < r ≤ n. This is the part of the array that can be cyclically shifted.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The number of cyclic shifts performed to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means that the solution must be efficient enough to sort the array within these constraints.

# [degree adverb]
    'already sorted'
    Explanation: If the array is already sorted, no cyclic shifts are needed, and the output should reflect this by setting k = 0.

# [code logic]
1. For each test case, read the length of the array and the array itself.
2. Check if the array is already sorted. If it is, output k = 0.
3. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements closer to their correct positions.
4. Perform cyclic shifts on identified segments, ensuring that the number of shifts does not exceed n.
5. Output the number of shifts and the details of each shift (l, r, d).

# [edge case]
    Test case with an already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with an array of length one:
    Input: [5]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: A single-element array is trivially sorted.

    Test case with all elements equal:
    Input: [7, 7, 7, 7]
    Output: 0
    Explanation: All elements are equal, so the array is already sorted.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle these edge cases. The original logic of checking if the array is already sorted before performing any operations will naturally handle these cases.

We will implement a function that sorts an array using cyclic shifts. The approach will involve selecting segments of the array and performing cyclic shifts to move elements into their correct positions. We will use a simple strategy that ensures the number of shifts does not exceed n, leveraging Python's list slicing capabilities for efficient manipulation.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'cyclic shift'
    Explanation: A cyclic shift involves rotating a segment of the array to the left by a specified offset, effectively rearranging the elements within that segment.

    'segment'
    Explanation: A segment is a contiguous subarray defined by two indices, l and r, within the array. This is the portion of the array that can be cyclically shifted.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'no more than n'
    Explanation: The requirement specifies that the number of cyclic shifts used to sort the array should not exceed the length of the array, n. This means we can perform up to n shifts to achieve sorting.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    1. For each test case, check if the array is already sorted. If it is, return k = 0.
    2. If not sorted, identify segments that can be cyclically shifted to move elements into their correct positions.
    3. Use a strategy to perform cyclic shifts, ensuring the number of shifts does not exceed n.
    4. For each shift, determine the indices l and r and the offset d.
    5. Apply the cyclic shift using Python's list slicing and concatenation.
    6. Track the number of shifts and output the result.

# [edge case]
    Test case with already sorted array:
    Input: [1, 2, 3, 4]
    Expected output: 0
    Explanation: The array is already sorted, so no shifts are needed.

    Test case with array of length one:
    Input: [5]
    Expected output: 0
    Explanation: An array with a single element is trivially sorted.

    Test case with all elements equal:
    Input: [3, 3, 3, 3]
    Expected output: 0
    Explanation: All elements are equal, so the array is already sorted.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic can handle these cases by checking if the array is already sorted or if it has a length of one.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of each test case description contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 50) — the length of the array. The second line consists of space-separated elements of the array a_i (-10^9 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^9). Elements of array a may repeat and don't have to be unique.

Output

Print t answers to all input test cases. 

The first line of the answer of each test case should contain an integer k (0 ≤ k ≤ n) — the number of actions to sort the array. The next k lines should contain descriptions of the actions formatted as "l r d" (without quotes) where l and r (1 ≤ l < r ≤ n) are the boundaries of the segment being shifted, while d (1 ≤ d ≤ r - l) is the offset value. Please remember that only the cyclic shifts to the left are considered so the chosen segment will be shifted by the offset d to the to the left.

Note that you are not required to find the minimum number of cyclic shifts needed for sorting. Any sorting method where the number of shifts does not exceed n will be accepted.

If the given array a is already sorted, one of the possible answers is k = 0 and an empty sequence of cyclic shifts.

If there are several possible answers, you may print any of them.

Example

Input


4
2
2 1
3
1 2 1
4
2 4 1 3
5
2 5 1 4 3


Output


1
1 2 1
1
1 3 2
3
2 4 1
2 3 1
1 3 2
4
2 4 2
1 5 3
1 2 1
1 3 1

Note

Explanation of the fourth data set in the example: 

  1. The segment a[2 … 4] is selected and is shifted to the left by 2: [2, \color{blue}{5, 1, 4}, 3] \longrightarrow [2, \color{blue}{4, 5, 1}, 3] 
  2. The segment a[1 … 5] is then selected and is shifted to the left by 3: [\color{blue}{2, 4, 5, 1, 3}] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 3, 2, 4, 5}] 
  3. After that the segment a[1 … 2] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{1, 3}, 2, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{3, 1}, 2, 4, 5] 
  4. And in the end the segment a[1 … 3] is selected and is shifted to the left by 1: [\color{blue}{3, 1, 2}, 4, 5] \longrightarrow [\color{blue}{1, 2, 3}, 4, 5]
